claim: A 4-year-old girl from a recently immigrated family presents to the emergency department with episodes of severe coughing lasting up to several minutes followed by vomiting. She had a low grade fever and runny nose over the last 2 weeks but these coughing episodes just began one day prior to presentation. A complete blood count shows a lymphocytic infiltrate and Gram stain reveals a gram-negative coccobacillus. The emergency department physician explains that this organism causes disease by toxin-mediated inactivation of an inhibitory signaling molecule. Which of the following could be used to culture the most likely cause of this disorder? : Charcoal yeast with iron and cysteine

supporting.text: The clinical presentation and Gram stain findings are consistent with Bordetella pertussis infection, which is best cultured on Charcoal yeast with iron and cysteine medium.

attacks.text: The clinical presentation and Gram stain findings are consistent with Bordetella pertussis infection, which is best cultured on Charcoal yeast with iron and cysteine medium.
The Gram stain findings could also be consistent with Haemophilus influenzae, which would require different culture conditions such as chocolate agar.
The lymphocytic infiltrate could be indicative of a viral infection, making bacterial culture irrelevant in this case.
Haemophilus influenzae typically presents with different symptoms such as epiglottitis or meningitis, not the classic whooping cough seen here.
The toxin-mediated mechanism described is highly specific to Bordetella pertussis, not seen in viral infections.
Atypical strains of Haemophilus influenzae can present with respiratory symptoms similar to pertussis, though rare.
Some viral infections can cause secondary bacterial infections, which might still require bacterial culture despite initial viral etiology.

supporting.text: Bordetella pertussis requires specific nutrients like iron and cysteine for growth, which are provided by the Charcoal yeast medium, making it the optimal choice for culture.

PCR-based methods have largely replaced culture for Bordetella pertussis diagnosis due to higher sensitivity and faster turnaround time.
